job_title: Senior Program Coordinator in Providence, RI
pros: The retirement match is 8 percent, which is okay but not sufficient when compared to peer institutions.
cons: They have a five-year vesting schedule for retirement contributions, which is absurd when so many peer institutions vest immediately with a 10% contribution instead of 8%. Employees have to pay a sizeable amount for health insurance instead of it being covered. Coordinator-level positions start at 46-48K, which is incredibly low in this economy and considering inflating. Other positions are also well below what they should pay. A lot of offices are also strangely committed to making staff work on-site even if they actually don't need to be on campus to carry out their work. If you're not going to pay staff enough to live comfortably in the Providence metro area, then make it easier for them to live farther away. You also have to pay for parking on campus even though public transportation to the campus is subpar at best. Brown might have been able to offer the salaries and benefits they did when this region was more affordable, but they are no longer appropriate for the cost of living here.

review_title: Great people & benefits, low salaries & opportunities for advancement
job_title: Varied Over Time But Academic Unit in Providence, RI
pros: People at Brown are genuinely smart and interesting and mostly very kind. Many lectures and events on campus are free, so if you want to immerse yourself in the intellectual community, it's easy to do so. The benefits are fantastic, particularly excellent health insurance, and at lower salary levels, you contribute very little towards the premium. Plus employees get lots of vacation/sick time, "summer hours," and the week off between Christmas and New Year's.
cons: Salaries are quite low, even compared to other area universities and research . And there are few opportunities for career advancement. Academia has very few structures in place to actually promote good employees and weed out the deadwood or incompetent.  Plus Brown itself still has a bit of an identity crisis as it wants to be a world-class university but until recently it was mostly a residential college so it has kind of a provincial attitude about certain things, particularly in admin units. Department Chairs are not HR managers, and sometimes can't recognize when someone really isn't pulling his or her weight - they aren't interested in investing their limited time to figure out systems and to advance careers for those who are actually competent. HR people are helpful but operate on a corporate model, and many academic jobs don't really fit into neat little boxes.

review_title: A great place to do a PhD - but be wary of the administration.
job_title: PhD Student, Biology in Providence, RI
pros: Faculty - in my department, the faculty are among the most well respected researchers in the field. They are often sought-after for advice by students and faculty from around the country. They advise well, and have an excellent track record of placing students at top post-doctoral and faculty positions around the country and world. Independent research is paramount, and the faculty allow you to pursue your research interests, regardless of whether or not they are in-line with their own research agenda. Compared to the cost of living, the graduate stipends are generous - I've been able to save in excess of $20K in my 5 years as a PhD student here. Other benefits are in line with peer institutions.
cons: The structure of the graduate program in Biology is odd, and leads to problems. Currently, the graduate program is structured within the Division of Medicine, which inevitably leads to a medical focus. If you work in an area of biology that is not directly applicable to medicine, your work is either marginalized or ignored by the deans. This leads to issues with graduate student funding - the model that is currently being pursued by the administration relies upon NIH R-1 levels of funding, which is not reasonable for many fields: comparative anatomy and physiology, functional morphology, ecology, evolutionary biology, botany, phylogenetics, and others. The division may have trouble retaining faculty in the near future if this is not changed.

review_title: A great place to work if you can find a good fit in the right department.
pros: Great benefits package -- the best I have seen anywhere. This is something you may not realize until you have worked a few other places. This includes not just health and dental, but very generous paid time off. The hours are really good as well -- some departments give flex time, allow you to work from home a little bit, etc. In the summer the work week is a little shorter, and even during the academic year the work week is only 37.5 hours. The campus is beautiful, and it is a pleasure to work with many of the professors on interesting projects.
cons: Some departments or sub-divisions of departments can be very hide-bound and traditionalist in their approach to things, rather than forward-thinking. Some management personnel definitely don't respect their employees (but others do -- it really depends on the department or sub-division of a given department). Mostly we're talking about IT-related positions. It's also true that as an IT professional you can get paid more in a corporate environment. Another downside to the academic world is that people become very insular and protective of their turf and their ideas, and not prone to trying out new technologies or ideas. Again though, this varies widely from one manager to the next.

review_title: It's all relative, but I'd bet this is one of the better places to be a postdoc or assistant prof.
pros: Surely professional environment is very field/department-specific, so if you're a prospective postdoc or junior faculty you're probably not reading glassdoor for reviews.  Maybe it will help someone to say that I was impressed by the many professional development opportunities offered at the university level, which were tailored to different domains (eg separately for sciences vs humanities et al) and covered many bases (eg teaching opportunities vs strategies for grant applications).  I participated in activities regarding teaching and grant preparation in the sciences, among other topics, and can say they were useful and well considered.  Very good support for newly hired junior faculty.
cons: While my department was willing to use my professional rather than legal name, that was not the case for the university-wide system (which controls course listings).  This is a minor issue, but a nuisance that likely affects more academic women than men.  Doesn't really count as a "con" for a job-seeker but this space has a 20-word minimum.

pros: Great Resources, Great Professors, Great Education
cons: This school is very expensive

pros: It's nice to be working for one of the main employers in the city and state. I like that the Brown ID card gets you free rides on public transportation across the state. And, depending on what department or center you are working with, it can be a great experience.
cons: I've worked a couple of different jobs here and in one case I was very happy, and in the other, not happy at all. It really depends on the department, center or group you are working with. There's not a lot of cross-department or cross-center community. Also, with people who were having conflicts at my previous job (where I was happy) and with me at my current not-so-great job, I observed that Human Resources was not very supportive or helpful. You're really on your own here.

review_title: Help Desk Consultant Job Pretty Chill
job_title: Computing & Information Services Help Desk Consultant in Providence, RI
pros: The staff in the CIS Help Desk are some of the most helpful and understanding I’ve ever had the pleasure of working with. I worked here part-time as I was a full-time student at the university. They were quite understanding of my student schedule, though they did want me to be as upfront about potential scheduling conflicts as possible (letting them know as soon as I knew, etc.).
cons: Most of the negative experiences in this position would have come from the tedium of working with Brown Wi-Fi issues (used to be called Brown-Secure, though it’s probably a different name/system now) or with particularly unpleasant interactions with community members (as in those we were tasked with helping).

job_title: Residence Hall Director in Providence, RI
pros: Many coworkers to lean on for support, resources, collaboration, and guidance; incredibly passionate, active, critically-thinking students; acceptable pay; beautiful area to live/work in;  good professional development opportunity.
cons: Upper-level administrators did not always display positive leadership. There was a lack of leadership from the top down that had large, negative impacts on both professional and student staff. This lack of communication, compassion, transparency, support, and organization made it difficult both day-to-day, as well as over the entire summer, to make true progress on certain projects, programs, policy changes, and grievances. Many students did not feel valued, validated, or supported by the leadership of the program and even their own direct supervisors.

review_title: Excellent school for studying and preparing for your future career.
pros: Brown is simply an excellent place to study and work for. Brown has great collaborative and supportive environment that give you a lot of support when studying and working. Most people here are really smart and independent. They come here because Brown is most freedom and they can choose what they want to do, what they want to study and what they want to prepare for their future career. Being one of the Ivy League schools, Brown has a number of excellent professors and lecturers that are well graduated from famous school like Harvard, Standford, MIT, Yale, Cornell, Berkeley etc.
cons: Brown is just a small school so not many fields of study to choose from. Career Center is mostly for undergraduate students, not for graduates. As a graduate, you will have to find your own way to get a job.

pros: There are a lot of good people at Brown. The campus environment is fun, dynamic, elegant, classy. If you have time to take advantage of them, there are loads of wellness and learning activities designed for staff - everything from workshops on healthy eating to taking care of elderly parents.
cons: There are 3,000 employees at Brown, and there are a few jaded employees who have been there a long time. For some reason, they are allowed to stay despite their bad attitudes. Also, the University is so large, it tends to become siloed - both in information and in culture. Departments vary greatly and some have better morale overall than others.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Providence, RI
pros: That's a great school, with a lot of opportunities of collaboration. It's great that postocs can get any courses in the University for free - some of them can be really useful for the future career (such as the teaching certificates for example). The major point for this University is also that it provides great benefits to postdocs (at a level of regular staff members): full medical and dental coverage, retirement plan, etc. The salary is competitive, and the location is great (you can easily afford living in 10 minutes on foot from your work).
cons: The tenured professors form a rather closed society, which does not seem to based entirely on scientific success, but also on personal "liking" and "disliking". There seems to be almost no hope to get a tenure-track position in this University..

review_title: absolutely awesome- but isolating without an outside network
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Providence, RI
pros: Loved my research, the professors for the most part are very nice, very intelligent and great to work with.  Exceptions to every rule, of course, but for the most part it's a really great research community.
cons: Loved my work, but my department (engineering) lacked much comradery among the other phd students in the program.  You really have to be pro-active in order to meet other people and make friends.  I'm originally from New England, otherwise I think I would have had a much harder time adjusting.

pros: Excellent benefits, hours, PTO, Healthcare
cons: UNIVERSITY EMERGENCY MEDICINE FOUNDATION IS A hostile workplace.  Management will do anything they can to cover their butts.  The do not follow employment laws, ADA Laws, FMLA laws.  No progressive discipline.  They fire anyone for any reason.  They consistently use the "you are an employee at will, we can fire for any reason at any time", to the extent that it effects employees morale.  Most administrative employees are concerned about being terminated at anytime because throughout the years it has happened on a regular basis.  Physicians are treated completely differently than administrative employee.  Management will lie, create false documentation, coerece other employee to lie and verbally abuse and harass and intimidate administrative personnel to get them to do what they want. Unprofessional managerial behavior.  Beware!

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Providence, RI
pros: Hands down the best students I've taught. Because the "New Curriculum" allows them to take only classes that interest them, with no distribution requirements, just about every student has selected your class out of thousands of others because it interests them, so they are smart and engaged.
cons: The administration is a bit conservative, and increasingly the Med School gets all of the money and buzz. The arts and humanities are not nearly as well funded. Also, there's an explicit change to tenure review; the administration wants to make it much harder to get tenure than it is now.

review_title: Exploitative with little to no advising, mentorship, or professional development
pros: Fully funded PhD — however that depends on your advisor having grants so many of my peers have had to apply for 10+ fellowships when their advisor fails to get grants. Access to thoughtful, kind, interesting faculty and students if you search for them.
cons: Huge disparity in the experience of individual graduate students. No standardization, extremely exploitative, treated as  disposable, little to no advising,  not collaborative, no management of the lab, and no professional development resources. No accountability for abusive tenured faculty. Very hierarchical.  I would never recommend Brown for graduate school — go work in industry where they have real HR, employee resource groups, team science, management and oversight, mentorship, professional development, and compensation that enables building financial stability.

job_title: Senior Technical Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Great work / life balance, for me.  Pleasant working environment.
cons: Unlike the custodians, electricians, and facilities maintenance personnel, Sr. TA's are non-union (also hourly employees), and are paid poorly.  The average Sr. TA earns less than a mid-scale custodian.  Also,  vacation accrues at a rate of 10 days per year, for hourly employees (first 2 years only, then increases to same as salaried employees).  For salaried employees, it accrues at a starting rate of 24 days per year, starting in the first year of employment. Kind of a cast system...at a so called progressive university.  Inequality exists here. Not sure why there is this discriminatory practice.  All people should be treated equally.  Simple.

job_title: Curriculum Writer & Researcher in Providence, RI
pros: An opportunity to learn about global and national historical/current events, a small team dedicated to personal and company improvement, real efforts for diversity and inclusion that may not be perfect but are human centered, striving to be honest, and truly caring. Also, in my experience pretty excellent leadership.
cons: If you prefer to be a small fish in a big sea (on a bigger team), this office culture may be too small for you. Also, there was some favoritism that led to a struggle in team cohesion. Overtime, this revealed itself as deconstructive. Team members do want to challenge their own biases, which is half the battle!

job_title: Operations and Events Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: There's great culture and support to be found if you have the time and flexibility to look/work for it. Many students, faculty, and staff share a true passion for the University and are encouraged to work harder in pursuit of common goals. The vacation and sick time package is a great perk, as is the free access to RIPTA.
cons: Salaries are lean. Very lean. And many departments are increasingly understaffed- so we are constantly asked to do more for (and with) less. Salaries do not increase to meet cost of living expenses, and don't always even increase enough to outweigh increased cost of benefits. I hope that Brown/Human Resources doesn't consider cutting back on too many of the existing perks, because it's one of the few ways to make working at the university financially viable.

pros: Brown provides a great environment in which to work. There is always something interesting going on, the people are collaborative and bright as a general rule.  Brown is a large employer so there are opportunities to change jobs and try new things.  The benefits are really good.  They close down every year around Christmas and non-essential staff are given time off. They have an insurance buy-out program.  It is a nice work/life balance.
cons: Employee parking is a big issue-take the bus if you can.  The school has an agreement with RIPTA and employees can ride for free.  Career paths are not clear cut for many positions. You have to find and pursue your own opportunities.  There are many applicants for every job-it can be hard to get in.

review_title: Nice benefits and atmosphere, but happiness depends on the people in your department
job_title: Biological Safety Specialist in Providence, RI
pros: Great benefits include healthcare, retirement, education, free bus pass and discount to the new fitness center. Rich in resources on and around campus. The pool is awesome, the piano practice rooms, the main green and libraries are all nice perks of working at a university.
cons: The office environment is not for me. Some of the people in my office were always complaining and never seemed happy or healthy, and they never did anything about it so it was depressing. It was hard to get these people to think or act differently.

pros: The employee benefits are the best I've ever had, I spend 0 time worrying about coverage for health/dental/etc.  Also, the work/life balance is best I've had.  They also provide a lot of valuable resources for their employees, makes life easier with less to worry about.
cons: Since it is a university, there is a lot of politics involved in how money is allocated and where priorities are placed.  I knew this going in though, so I've always had in mind to be patient, but it can sometimes feel a little redundant.

review_title: There are a lot of great people at Brown, and the city of Providence is an outstanding place to live and work.
pros: There are a lot of dedicated and intelligent people working there. The location is great, with terrific food and culture for such a small city. Some nights and weekends, but overall a good work/life balance is encouraged - we had a fairly flexible schedule as long as you finished your work.
cons: It is difficult to advance unless people retire or move to different positions; compensation in academic world not great compared to what you might receive in private sector. At the time that I was there it was difficult economically - wage/hiring freezes led to some poor morale, although that may have improved since.

pros: Brown offers a flexible work environment.  Graduate students have complete autonomy.  The fellowships offered are reasonable.  The other graduate students are interesting.
cons: The requirements are not well communicated.  The structure of the graduate school feels disorganized.  Your success depends entirely on your advisor.

review_title: Every day is an upstream battle against the status quo.
pros:
- It's prestigious (an Ivy league school)
- Benefits are fantastic
- The location is great for anyone who enjoys restaurants and fun.
cons:
- IT Offices are cramped and colorless
- Many employees are underpaid compared to their peers in the industry.
- You're expected to not speak up about problems so that people don't look bad.
- Most people have had so many additional responsibilities thrust on them that they're miserable to work with.
- Most people are not accountable and will do everything they possibly can from raising their hand in a meeting to take ownership of a given task for fear of being blamed when something goes wrong.

review_title: No employee protection or room for advancement
pros: I didn't utilize health benefits, but I was told comparatively they are ok.
cons: Quite frankly, as a former long term employee of Brown I would strongly advise against employment here much to the contrary of what most people think. There is very little support for employees once you are an actual employee. Managers rule here, and employees word carries very little weight. The University and Med School side operate on very different planes and both are quite political and are hesitant to work together when a situation arises. Everything is all smoke and mirrors - for good PR - that's all.

review_title: Like any graduate program, great place to work if you have the right boss.
pros: People are pretty flexible, though it depends who your direct boss is.  Departments can feel insulated from the general university, which means that graduate students generally don't have to worry about university politics.  Faculty are generally friendly and supportive.
cons: Long hours best describe a graduate student's life, but this is true anywhere.  Support greatly depends on the department and professor a student is working for, so funding may or may not be an issue.

pros: The faculty are among the top in the field.  Great hands on experience for those wanting a future in a science and technology field.
cons: Facilities are not the best.  There isn't much to do in Providence besides hang out with your friends.  I would recommend taking the RIPTA for free into Newport which is a very fun city.

review_title: Demanding workplace with a collaborative and supportive environment
pros: Mine is a prestigious department with very high expectations for graduate students, but I've never felt like i was on my own trying to achieve it all. The faculty and staff are incredibly supportive; I have always felt like I have a whole team behind me who are invested in my success. Guaranteed funding makes for a strong sense of security, too.
cons: Teaching is not really a priority of many of the departments here, and the teaching certificate program the university offers is very fluffy. It would be better to have teacher training more integrated with the TA experience, more of a mentorship.

review_title: Not a place for growth and real intelectual excitement beyond undergard
pros: Great place work full time as an administrator or tenured faculty. Nice benefits and easy going environment.
cons: Not much potential for growth in certain departments. Too much time is spent with keeping up appearances and not enough time spent achieving goals.

review_title: Strong graduate program in molecular biology, cell biology, and biochemistry
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Providence, RI
pros:
The graduate program is rigorous and very useful.  
There's a limited number of classes to take and you're usually done by your second or third year.
You only have to TA a single semester-- and this is also completed in your second year
Your qualifying exam is based on your thesis project and is more of a research proposal, this is finished in the second year.
Graduate students and NOT postdocs are the focus.  
Professors and PIs really care about their students
cons: Although the avg graduate time is 5.5 years, a number of students take longer (6-7 years) to graduate

review_title: More of a family than an employer
job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Providence, RI
pros: Great working environment, friendly co-workers, great benefits and lots of available training and education. Working in the Computer Science department is NEVER boring.  =)
cons: Difficult morning commute and the parking lots are expensive to get in to.  Street parking is just a short walk away, but it's limited.  There are no designated parking spaces for scooters/motorcycles, but there are plenty of bike racks.  And the city is still trying to get use to removing snow and ice in the winter, but the University does a great job of keep their buildings cleared.

review_title: Decent pair, very fair hours, understanding bosses. Great culture
pros: Loved the people - I had excellent supervisors and coworkers throughout my time here. Almost all were committed to the job and worked hard to provide good service. The pay was very fair and the benefits were nice.
cons: WAY too many offices doing the same work without talking to one another. Extremely frustrating to have your work vetoed by a department head you've never even met because the inter-office communication is so bad.

job_title: Artemis Project Coordinator in Providence, RI
pros: My summer working for the Artemis project was amazing. I learned even more about coding by teaching it and all of the girls that were apart of the 2015 class made the experience more than worthwhile. I would highly recommend this to anybody seeking to empower women in computer science and anybody looking to improve their own knowledge of computer science
cons: There's no housing stipend, but you do get compensated for being a coordinator, so you're able to pay to stay in Providence.

review_title: Does not Pay Admin Staff Appropriately; does not recognize the contribution of Admins
pros:
Benefits are decent if you stay at least 5 years and then the 4 years for you child to attend college.
RISD, PC, RWU and many others have much better benefits.
cons:
Pay is lousy and they know it, admitted in in President Simmons letter stating admins are paid 6% on average lower than the surrounding area for the same jobs.  To compensate, they decided on a pool of 2% to increase salaries  2011.  Do the math, with an increase below inflation when we were already 6% below the average, we continue to lose money every year we stay there.

The amount of work administrative staff are expected to do and the vast diversity of that work with the constantly changing "experiments" and software makes it impossible to do the great job we want to do.  Being unappreciated doesn't help.  Though you may hear thanks from faculty, the thanks is never relflected in the pay check.  They also charge us over $500 to park!!!  Not to mention, they took away our benefit of free gym membership, so we lost another nearly $400 if you count that as slaary.  They steal from the poor to give to the rich at the university.  I don't make enough to live here or to work at Brown and I only have one child to support.  It's not a living wage!

pros: The Department of Earth, Environmental and Planetary Sciences is excellent. There is a strong collaborative atmosphere, and a lot to learn from colleagues.
cons: The department is not the best when it comes to supporting visa issues with international postdocs, especially when the postdoc has a strong ground for justification for a particular situation.

review_title: Positive experience as student researcher and teaching assistant
pros: Networking is a strong possibility with the impressive faculty at Brown. Supervisors and professors are willing to give you the benefit of the doubt and time to do other work when the going gets tough.
cons: Sometimes more time commitment than is realistically possible is expected of a student who is employed at Brown. They expect you to be good at balancing a course load and a work load.

pros:
Helpful admin staff in HR departments
Productive team of colleagues 
Opportunities for learning for staff through staff professional development workshops
Interesting invited guest speakers in the dept.
cons:
Research opportunities for non-Brown University graduate level researchers are limited
Some senior faculty are not able to offer encouragement and career support because they are very selective in who they endorse 
More expensive to study at, but of course university's renowned reputation matters

review_title: Overall not bad but there are better on campus
pros: Close to campus, get to meet people you might not have otherwise, pretty relaxed environment, free food, wage increase every semester
cons: strict hours, early hours, hair nets, some annoying/entitled students(thought most are very polite), hours are not flexible, for most positions you can't do homework at the same time (which is possible for many other on campus jobs)

job_title: Clinical Psychology Resident in Providence, RI
pros: A wide variety of clinical opportunities. Also, the faculty are very helpful and have your professional development as their top priority. My job opportunities have increased since coming to Brown.
cons: There are no major cons as far as I can tell. The salary, of course, could be higher, but the current salary is in line with other internship placements across the region.

pros: The prestigious university has its perks and is a good place to start a career. The name carries weight in research sectors so that is a plus.
cons: Parking is scarce, good luck finding a spot. The University does not offer parking, unless you pay hundreds of dollars a year. Management was good, but a bit stuffy.  Without an advanced degree they seemed condescending.

review_title: Great IVY school, robust culture and flexibility in study plans
pros: flexible on making your own study plans. I am in the Chemistry PhD program, but I really like entrepreneurship. So Brown offer me the scholar ship to do a secondary master's in entrepreneurship along the way.
cons: I'd say, the fundamental components of STEM programs are really strong. The academic performance is great. However, there can be more help on career development for grad students.

pros: The University is not so big that most of us don't know each other.  You do feel the rich history of the school as you travel around campus.
cons: Sometimes you wonder if their is true support to all of the faculty and staff members.  You tend to feel that their is the elite class and the rest of us.

review_title: Great Benefits, Poor salary for most administrative roles
pros: Benefits including tuition reimbursement for employees, $10k towards dependent's tuition and health care costs on a sliding scale essentially based on your salary.
cons: Poor infrastructure, poor support, poor training of staff.  No plan in place to promote within.  Salary notoriously low and benefits shrink, cost of parking increases, free gym membership no longer exists.  Open during hazardous weather conditions.

review_title: Review Brown from a graduate student
pros:
!. nice and safe living area: it is in a small town but close to Boston and New York.
2. Brown provide decent economic support for graduate students and cares students a lot about their living and mental healthy.
3. Brown is one of the top universities in US indicating its outstanding academic standing. 
3. Providence has a lot high ranking restaurants around.
cons: Brown is a small university, which makes slightly troublesome in finding related cooperators.

pros: Brown University's Department of Molecular Pharmacology, Physiology, and Biotechnology truly focuses on teaching it's employees and students the full "ins and outs" of lab-based research; fully preparing them for research jobs.
cons: There is no downtime in the graduate programs at Brown University Department of Molecular Pharmacology, Physiology, and Biotechnology, which leaves students/employees tired and overworked most of the time, yet still happy and optimistic.

pros: supportive staff, beautiful campus, and relative safe in the east side.  Benefits are good, health, dental ,life insurance... Salary level is competitive among the universities.
cons: parking is hard, and salary is just OK. It has the drawbacks of small university, like faculty controls too much and won't give much space for different research ideas.

job_title: Program & Communications Coordinator in Providence, RI
pros: Brown University is a place of much professional and intellectual diversity, offering a range of options through which to combine personal development and growth in abilities and in a vision of what you hope to accomplish in work and in life.
cons: Limited opportunity for promotion given the university structure and occasional emphasis on student-centricity rather than worker-improvement and respect for needs of staff.

pros: It really depends on the professor you work for, but I had a lot of fun being a teaching assistant at the undergraduate and graduate levels. Brilliant bosses and coworkers, good environment, flexible schedule.
cons: Low pay, no benefits, Brown's administrators can be pretty disorganized and getting my W-2 and setting up payroll was pretty arduous.

pros: Intellectually stimulating environment, if you seek it out.  Work Life balance, vacation time, health care benefits, retirement plan benefit, tuition reimbursement.
cons: Poor support for growth, poor management, staff is not valued.  It doesn't feel like a liberal work environment, it feels like a republican run corporation.

pros: Brown is a great place to work and the benefits, such as healthcare, are top notch.  The university really does reach out to show the faculty and staff that they are valued within the Brown community.
cons: From a scientific stand point, academic research is not all that well funded and can move slowly at times, but that has less to do with Brown itself and more with the structure of how scientific research is funded as a whole.

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student in the life sciences
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Providence, RI
pros:
Collaboration is the norm, and people are friendly and open.
Good core facilities.
Good support system for graduate students, stipend is excellent given the cost of living.
cons:
Can be hard to get career advice for careers outside academia for PhDs.
Disconnect between the graduate school and the division of biology and medicine.

pros: Great health insurance, time off and wellness programs, as well as training opportunities.
cons: Pay is a bit low, even though the benefits are good. It is hard to move up a pay grade. There is no real career trajectory. It seems there is a big gap between senior administrative positions and the worker bees.

pros: Beautiful campus, nice environment, nice people.
cons: Bureaucracy can be archaic for little things. Changing your office furniture, installing a table outside a building, getting help on a website, all this stuff can be slow or impossible. Institutional Review Board folks have been very difficult and frustrating to work with.

pros: The pay was good and the job was really fun.  The class was great and gave me an opportunity to try my hand at teaching.
cons: They didn't do online time sheets so everything was by paper which was kind of a pain.  It would be nice if they did online time sheets.

review_title: Easiest job to get, but keep looking for something better while you work
pros:
Very easy job to get
Allows students to socialize while at work
Free meals with every shift
cons:
Has no resume value 
You  will probably see the worst aspects of the student body
Some of the managers are so jaded and awful

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Brown is a great environment to work, people are supportive and the compensation for being a TA was reasonable. The student quality is also very high and makes teaching courses that much more valuable.
cons: Some cons are while the vast majority are of great quality, sometimes student effort was not very high. However, this may have been an anomaly with the courses I was assigned.

job_title: Student Research Associate in Providence, RI
pros: Love It! I get to work with very intellectual people every day and everyone is always wanting to know more!
cons: I currently do not have any negative things to say about Brown University as it is a great place to work and I love being here!

job_title: IT Consultant/Undergraduate TA in Providence, RI
pros: There are great opportunities to give back to the TA programs that run many departments here, convenient to work on campus, and it's a great way to make a bit of money during the year
cons: It's really hard to be a TA, people don't show up to office hours with help but rather with anger and frustration for you, low pay, and "raises" are only $0.10 per semester.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Providence, RI
pros: Collegial department atmosphere, reasonable stipend and benefits, research travel funding, gain teaching experience
cons: The "pros" are determined by which department you are in; limits for work outside of the University.

pros: Great benefits beyond the typical.  RIPTA is free to all Brown employees;  100 hours of low-cost home care when family members are sick or kids have school vacations; good matches for retirement, 24 vacation days from the start.
cons: The work is sometimes dull and working through the bureaucratic web of a large university can be slow going.

review_title: Long hours, little appreciation, antiquated technology
pros: Retirement plan, vacation time, summer hours
cons: Lots of overtime with no additional pay.  Not enough staff.  Negative culture - there is no recognition for achievement.  Upper level management is detached from organization and doesn't realize (or doesn't care) what is going on in the trenches.

pros: freely research, a lot of time to think, low pressure, nice professors, nice fellows, good resources, good opportunity to work with different people.
cons: the tempo got a little bit slow some time, well, you can't really complain about it. the department is kind of small

review_title: very good diverse place to work
pros: You will meet interesting people.  Great tuition benefit for your children either at Brown or any other institution.
cons: Parking.  You will have to pay to park and there is a waiting list for the good lots

pros:
- steep learning curve. 
- great pay.
- fun job.
- nice and friendly coworkers and employer. 
- suitable work load.
cons:
- sometimes we work late. 
- should submit articles asap.
- taking good photos for publication can be challenging at times.

review_title: A very supportive and strong community
pros: Strong community atmosphere. Excellent benefits. Supportive administration, understanding and humane in expectation. Beautiful city.
cons: Somewhat corporate ethos. Expectation of "loyalty" to the university - pulling "extra hours" for university events even on national holidays. Student community can act somewhat entitled and rude to staff. Parking is horrible.

pros: Plenty of resources, very competitive stipend and benefits for a full 5 years, opportunities to work with faculty from different departments
cons: PhD students are treated with little respect; a general "trial by fire" attitude breeds unhealthy competition and a total lack of cooperation amongst students; the majority of faculty members publicly refused to comply with accommodations requests from Student and Employee Accessibility Services

pros: Good if you are interested in graduate studies, else use your time else where.  PhD takes time and commitment, not for every one.
cons: some times graduate students can feel isolated, Brown is geared towards undergraduates. I guess the situations has been brought up a number of times.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Access to all resources in RI. Very supportive faculty. Excellent graduate students and undergraduates. Relatively low stress environment and good work life balance. Providence is a great entrepreneurial city.
cons: Research resources are at times limited. Sometimes not enough network opportunities to build relationships with outside Brown scientist.

review_title: Great opportunity for growth in research
pros: Learned a lot about the work involved in social sciences research and data management; I have a supportive supervisor
cons: I wished there was more funding through the university for these types of social science research jobs

job_title: Academic Department Manager in Providence, RI
pros: Excellent benefits and opportunities to experience events, lectures and other offerings on campus.  Friendly faculty and administrative team.
cons: Administratively it can challenging, given hierarchical culture and operational inefficiencies.  Competing priorities due to lack of capacity planning.

pros: Very ethical organization; HR is superb; leadership is great; sense of community
cons: Salary is very low and it is hard to get a raise

pros: beautiful campus, all kinds of student-run organization, freedom of speech and rally, a great gym with fantastic fitness center, a multifunctional busy street with all types of restaurants.
cons: small campus, it seems there is no other great place around campus to hang out with friends except place mall in downtown. some departments are a little small

pros: This is a good place to work, nice work/life balance, ethical employer, lots of extra perks, good work environment, nice people, tuition reimbursement program, good for people with kids
cons: limited growth opportunity for some, parking can be problematic, pay seems low for some positions,

review_title: Brown is a good place for student
pros: People in Brown are very nice. I work in a lab of engineering department and this is a perfect place for doing research.
cons: Brown engineering department is very small. So you can not find that many people can help you. But that is also good for us to get the self-motivation.

pros: Being a tutor was probably the best job on campus. The hours are flexible and the clients were always grateful for your help. Management is very friendly, accommodating, and always open to suggestions from the tutors. Pay raises based on performance reviews.
cons: None that I can think of

review_title: Applications Manager and Tech Project Lead
pros: Ivy League Higher Ed - Working hard to providing the world with brilliant graduates and amazing research.  4 weeks vacation and one week off paid for winter holiday break - 37.5 hours a week.
cons: Poor increases, high medical, and 37.5 hours are in the work week, but hard to come under 50.

job_title: Group Tutor/Tutor Leader in Providence, RI
pros:
*For group tutors*
- Personalized hours
- Excellent training and professional development opportunities
- Opportunities for advancement, such as serving on advisory board
- Chance to help other students and learn from them while reviewing old content: very practical and rewarding.
cons: For non tutors, wages are low and hours are more inflexible.

pros: It was great research opportunity. I got to establish good relation with my professor. I learned a lot about scientific research techniques and adapted into a lab environment. Co-workers are very intelligent and helpful.
cons: The payment nearly or not all covered the expenses. It was a bit lonely to work on campus during summer

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Bristol, RI
pros: People are smart, easy to get along with. President has a sincere in net rest in all employees and has office hours for any employee to schedule a meeting to talk about anything. Staff Development Day is great for all.
cons: The bus ride into Providence. Really no cons for the University itself.

pros:
Great colleagues
Free health insurance (for graduate students)
High-quality facilities
Many resources on campus to help students find jobs
cons:
No summer pay, though this appears to have changed recently.
Some graduate students run out of funding before they can finish degree

pros:
Great Health Benefits
Handful of small University perks like the occasional catered meal
cons:
Low Pay
No parking - street parking only or pay to be put in a lottery for private lots

review_title: Go to a bigger research university if you love research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Ivy title; opportunities to get a second master's degree from a completely different field; lots of collaborations; interdisciplinary research
cons: small school; not many PIs to choose from; if you don't like your PI, its hard to find another fit in the same department (again, small school).

pros: Great benefits, hours, and environment.  It is great being a part of academia and getting all the benefits - bus passes, gym membership, use of facilities, etc.
cons: My office had terrible organization and oversight.  Befuddling that an ivy league institution would have such madness.

pros: Intellectually challenging.  Most coworkers were great, hard working, and committed to what they were doing. Nothing complacent about the university. Pay was good.
cons: Staffing is too thin.  Way too much work for people and time available.  Expectations and pressure high.  Worked way more than full-time hours. Internal politics.

review_title: Great University for Grad and Post-doc Studies
pros: Grad students get dental, aid with eye exam costs, and great staff that really care about their students. Post-docs get great health care and good support from staff.
cons: Has similar cons as any graduate institution. Do your research and consider where you'd like to go wisely.

review_title: My experience as a Teaching and Research Fellow (as PhD student)
pros: Lots of resources for students, good stipend and funding (in the sciences at least). Grad students are generally treated with respect.
cons: No dental coverage provided in the student health insurance plan. The supplemental insurance one can purchase is a terrible deal.

pros: Great medical benefits , nice staff as well
cons: People need to wake up and see how valuable the little ppl are.. we work hard but don't seem to get respect or paid as well as we should

job_title: French Language Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Lots of flexibility regarding hours and level of students taught, freedom to create and implement my lesson plans as I saw fit, ability to assume responsibility for students and make independent choices without needing to jump through hoops for supervisors/professors
cons: None; I would've stayed on if I hadn't graduated

review_title: socially and intellectually fulfilling and challenging.
job_title: PhD Student, Engineering in Providence, RI
pros: Nice city/neighborhood, nice food and amenities with decent working environment.
cons: still exploring but not enough emphasis on graduate students, but I can feel the dynamics is gradually changing for the better.

pros: You get to talk about poetry all day, your teaching assignment involves teaching really really smart kids, and there are adequate colleagues.
cons: The anti-union policies mean that the administration can unilaterally change work policies/funding policies, without warning or consultation. The hours suck (so does all grad school, though).

pros: Good location, close to boston and new york city and Providence is a beautiful city. People here are nice. Salary is above average level for graduate students
cons: campus is small and kind of crowd. Parking place is very needed. graduate students are less concerned than undergraduate

job_title: Ph D Student in Providence, RI
pros: Awesome network and culture among graduate students.  Lots of opportunities for career development.  Faculty members truly care about the success and well-being of students.
cons: Grad school is very difficult and can be demoralizing over time (but this is not particular to Brown).

pros:
Very Relaxed place, University gives lot of freedom to choose  courses , projects etc from different department.

Great community, great city to be. Very close to Boston and New York.
cons: That would depend on the adviser, my adviser is very easy going. I never had any issue

pros: Great working environment, insurance buy-out program, generous vacation time, and many on-site events you can attend for free, RIPTA Bus pass
cons: salaries are low for some jobs, parking is an issue depending on your location, congested area, not much opportunity for growth in some areas

pros: Fundamental emphasis on academics. Good work-life balance for Ph.D student. The cost of living is somewhat better than other Ivy schools.
cons: Industry connection is not very strong. Also career support is weak.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Providence, RI
pros: Biomedical engineering at Brown is really great. You can always talk with smart people from multi-disciplines and get valuable advice from them.
cons: The amount of work you deal with is challenging. You need to find a way to balance you life and work.

review_title: Great place for growth and opportunity
pros: Great community, plenty of opportunities for professional development, amazing benefits
cons: Work life balance depends on office and team you work with. Was expected to be on call outside of office hours, even though it was not a part of the job description.

review_title: Mileage may vary -- choose your advisor carefully.
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Providence, RI
pros: Great community of supportive graduate students. Misery breeds bonds.
cons: Department heads don't put students first. Work-life balance is hard for departments to understand. Beware if you're a female or a POC as you may not be as supported as you'd like.

job_title: Admission and Enrollment Specialist in Providence, RI
pros: Benefits, location, culture, colleagues, pay, opportunity for advancement, forward-thinking
cons: Sometimes the bureaucratic culture of HR can hold you back (esp. when it comes to negotiating salary or securing leave)

pros: We were paid well for students and got a chance to spend time with profs and not a huge time commitment.
cons: It sometimes seemed like the prof did not really know how to mentor students and teach us how to be teaching assistants.

review_title: Brown University is a great place to work for!
pros: Paid summer week, 10 sick days, full dental, medical, and childcare
cons: Weather can be rough in the winter and work can be cancelled because of New England weather conditions

pros:
1.  Great place to work
2.  Great Faculty and interesting students that make life always exciting.  
3.  Well-respected institution with a good reputation.
cons: No big cons really - possibly getting adjusted to RI.

review_title: Mostly on your own, not much support from the senior level
pros: Providence is a lively city. Commute to work is easy. Brown is an ivy league school.
cons: Generally the school is stingy to treat its professors well. It went downhill after Robert Zimmer left for Chicago.

pros: Great healthcare benefits, flexibility in work schedule, opportunity to expand responsibilities beyond job description.
cons: Recognition not necessarily commensurate with performance.

review_title: Great academic research environment and there are many faculty open to collaborations.
pros: Great benefits, new facilities and resources for biomedical research, there are many perks in providence for brown employees a well.
cons: Things can take a while to be completed on the administrative end.

pros: Great benefits, great city, nice to work with brilliant professors/doctors, enjoyable working in academia
cons: No mechanism for removing toxic/apathetic employees, pay discrepancies, resistance to/insufficient support for education/career development for employees

pros: So much support. It is a tight knit community so you really feel at ease and feel as though you can approach anyone for help or advice.
cons: Occasionally stressful, but that is part of working for a high caliber institution.

job_title: Undergraduate Head Teaching Assistant in Providence, RI
pros:
Work with students and friends as a TA while you learn other skills as a student
Great sense of community
cons: Low wage and marginal bonuses per semester

job_title: Lead Systems Administrator in Providence, RI
pros: Unbeatable benefits packages, flexible hours for salaried employees w/ telecommute options, stable positions.
cons: Usually limited career growth opportunities, total compensation is on the low end of competitive. Some benefits are difficult to use.

pros: Has to be one of the top employers in the state. Excellent work environment and benefits.
cons: Everything happens by committee. It's hard to make changes or even get a project underway. But once it starts, the procedure is clear.

pros:
- flexible work attitude
- surrounded by intellectuals
- reasonable hours (no pressure to work extra)
- interesting work
cons: no real cons, could have been paid more elsewhere but the environment and benefits are worth it.

pros: Strong academic environment, commitment to diligence, quality, data; open communication environment.
cons: Big organization, lots of channels to navigate when working on a cross-functional project; politics (typical in academia).

review_title: wonderful time, fun people, good students
pros: good benefits, relaxing pace and room for growth
cons: there were no cons at this job

review_title: Great people, great atmosphere, honest work
pros: I interned with Brown University and everyone is very polite and caring. The hiring process is straightforward and HR is very courteous to one's needs.
cons: Could be difficult to work while in school.

pros:
Brown offers the possibility to meet and work with lots of great scientific minds
Brown had put a research culture that fosters the sharing knowledge and build new collaborations across disciplines.
cons: I have none to mention

pros: Sound pay, flexible hours, respectful upper management
